PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case the circuit court remanded the case to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to make specific findings of fact.Â  We dismiss the appeal.
FACTS
Joey Gray asserts he injured his back while driving a fork lift in the course and scope of his employment with Georgetown Steel.Â  Gray also claims he suffered hearing loss due to exposure to industrial noise during his employment with Georgetown Steel.Â  The single commissioner (the Commissioner) concluded Gray suffered a thirty-five percentage loss of use of the back.Â  The Commissioner did not award compensation for the hearing loss.Â  Georgetown Steel and its insurance carrier, Capital City Insurance Company (Insurance Company), appealed to the Full Commission.Â  
 
The Full Commission affirmed the Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law.Â  On appeal to the circuit court, the court ruled that the Commissioner and the Full Commission failed to make specific findings of facts relating to the hearing loss issue.Â  Thus, the circuit court remanded the case.Â  Georgetown Steel and Insurance Company appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order to remand.
LAW/ANALYSIS

App. 1985) (â€œ[A]n appeal from a Circuit Court order remanding a workersâ€™ compensation case for the purpose of making specific findings of fact is interlocutory and not reviewable by this court.â€).Â  Thus, we dismiss the appeal.
 
APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]Â

title: Cade v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Roywickus Cade, Respondent
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-371
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed September 18, 2007

REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Lance S. Boozer, Assistant Attorney General Karen Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Roywickus Cade filed an application for post-conviction relief (â€œPCRâ€), seeking to vacate his conviction and fifteen-year sentence for armed robbery.[1]Â  While the PCR judge found Cadeâ€™s trial counsel was not ineffective, he found appellate defense counsel was so and granted Cade a new trial rather than another opportunity to seek appellate review.Â  The State appeals.Â  We granted certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s decision.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[2]
The facts surrounding Cadeâ€™s conviction and sentence, which stem from the robbery of a convenience store, may be found in State v. Cade, Op. No. 02-UP-196 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 14, 2002).
1.Â  We first address the issue of whether the PCR judge erred in allowing Cade, over the Stateâ€™s objection, to amend his claim during the post-conviction hearing to assert appellate counsel provided Cade â€œineffective assistance.â€
The PCR judge conducted an evidentiary hearing on November 15, 2004.Â  Near the start of the hearing, Cadeâ€™s PCR counsel indicated Cadeâ€™s application for PCR included an allegation that both his trial and appellate counsel gave Cade ineffective assistance.Â  When, during Cadeâ€™s testimony the issue of appellate counselâ€™s effectiveness resurfaced, counsel for the State objected, contending that the issue had not been raised in Cadeâ€™s application, that Cadeâ€™s accompanying memorandum referenced only the allegations of ineffective assistance of trial counsel, and that Cade had not filed any additional memorandums in the two-year period between the filing of his application and the date of the hearing that alleged ineffective assistance of appellate counsel.Â  Counsel underscored the Stateâ€™s objection, saying, â€œI feel like weâ€™re just getting this sprung on us today . . . .â€
In response, Cade argued that, because his application listed the name of his appellate counsel and included a citation to Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1977) and Manson v. Brathwaite, 432 U.S. 98 (1977),[3] it was sufficient to infer therefrom an allegation of ineffective assistance of appellate counsel.
The PCR judge, in effect, allowed Cade to go forward with his challenge to the representation afforded him by appellate counsel, effectively amending Cadeâ€™s application.
The Uniform Post-Conviction Procedure Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to 160 (2003), governs the procedure for PCR proceedings.Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 363, 527 S.E.2d 742, 746 (2000).Â  The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure also apply to PCR proceedings, but only to the extent they are not inconsistent with the Act.Â  Rule 71.1, SCRCP.Â  Under the Act, an applicant must â€œspecifically set forth the grounds upon which the application is basedâ€ and include in his or her application those facts that are within the applicantâ€™s â€œpersonal knowledgeâ€ and set them out â€œseparately from other allegations of facts.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-50 (2003).Â  The Act also requires â€œ[a]ll grounds for relief available to an applicant . . . [to] be raised in his [or her] original, supplemental, or amended application.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-90 (2003).
The Act permits the PCR judge, â€œwhen appropriate,â€ to allow an â€œamendment of the application . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 17-27-70(a) (2003).Â  By the same token, Rule 15(a), SCRCP, permits â€œ[a] party [to] amend his [or her] pleading once as a matter of course at any time before or within 30 days after a responsive pleading is served . . . .â€Â  Beyond that, however, whether a party may amend his or her application, as with any other pleading, rests within the sound discretion of the PCR judge. Â See Simpson v. Moore, 367 S.C. 587, 599, 627 S.E.2d 701, 708 (2006) (noting a PCR judge may allow a petitioner to amend pleadings pursuant to Rule 15(b), SCRCP). Â The trial courtâ€™s decision whether to allow an amendment will not be reversed on appeal absent a showing of an abuse of discretion. Â See Mylin v. Allen-White Pontiac, Inc., 281 S.C. 174, 180, 314 S.E.2d 354, 357 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œCourts have wide latitude in amending pleadings and, while this power should not be exercised indiscriminately or to surprise or prejudice an opposing party, the matter of allowing amendments is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge. His decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion or unless manifest injustice has been done.â€).
We hold the PCR judge did not abuse that discretion in this instance by allowing Cade to attack his appellate counsel and, in effect, amending his application.Â  The State failed to demonstrate any legal prejudice.Â  Indeed, the State failed to ask for a continuance and chose not to subpoena the appellate counsel in question, choosing instead to take refuge behind the requirement that the burden of proof on the issue of the insufficiency of appellate counsel lay with the applicant.
2.Â  We next address whether the PCR judge erred in holding Cade was entitled to a new trial because his appellate counsel provided him ineffective assistance.Â  The PCR judge grounded his holding on appellate counselâ€™s failure to appeal issues involving the identification of Cade as a participant in the robbery for which Cade was convicted and appellate counselâ€™s failure to raise an issue â€œright on appealâ€ that related to a common scheme and plan involving a carjacking.
Regarding the identification issues, and notwithstanding the PCR judgeâ€™s view that â€œtrial counsel . . . did an outstanding job in preserving these issues,â€ we are of a different opinion. Â These issues were not preserved, and, because they were not, appellate counsel cannot be faulted for not having raised them before the court of appeals.[4]Â  Legge v. State, 349 S.C. 222, 225, 562 S.E.2d 618, 620 (2002); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (â€œIn order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised and ruled upon by the trial judge.â€).
As to the common scheme or plan issue not being properly raised by appellate counsel before the court of appeals, that issue also affords Cade no basis for relief.Â  To show that counsel was deficient, an applicant for post-conviction relief on the basis of ineffective assistance of counsel must establish that counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms and the deficient performance prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687-88 (1984); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 117-18, 386 S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989).Â  Although appellate counsel argued, and lost, before the court of appeals the issue that the trial court erred in admitting evidence of Cadeâ€™s participation in a carjacking before the robbery, he failed to challenge the denial of Cadeâ€™s motion for a directed verdict at trial on the ground, argued by trial counsel, that the State did not link the carjacking to the robbery.Â  His failure to do so, however, caused Cade no prejudice.Â  Even without that evidence, other, more direct, evidence tied Cade to the robbery and thus provided sufficient evidence, when viewed in the light most favorable to the state, on which to base a denial of Cadeâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  See State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 64, 447 S.E.2d 177, 181 (1993) (holding a trial court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State when entertaining a defendantâ€™s motion for directed verdict).
3.Â  Regarding the claim of ineffective assistance of trial counsel, the PCR judge held that Cade â€œfailed to establish that his trial counsel was ineffective.â€Â  Because Cade does not appeal this holding and it is now the law of the case, we are obliged to affirm it.Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 72, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005).
REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  Daniel T. Stacey of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense perfected an appeal on Cadeâ€™s behalf.Â  The court of appeals affirmed Cadeâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  State v. Cade, Op. No. 2002-UP-196 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed March 14, 2002).
[[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Â Cade cited both cases as they relate to the factors a court must consider in determining the reliability of identification evidence.
[4]Â  Although the trial court held an in camera hearing on the photo line-ups and the identifications of Cade, Cadeâ€™s counsel at trial did not attempt to suppress the identifications on the basis that the out-of-court identifications were unreliable under Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1977).Â  The memorandum that accompanied Cadeâ€™s application even complains that â€œsince [trial] counsel failed to file a suppression motion on the [S]tateâ€™s identification testimony/evidence, this failure constituted ineffective assistance of counsel that prejudice[d] applicantâ€™s right to a fair trial and due process of law.â€

title: State v. Bagwell and Spain
text:
THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of
Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Steve R. Bagwell and Daryl Lee Spain, Appellants
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  C. Victor Pyle,
  Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished
Opinion No. 2007-UP-377
Submitted
  September 14, 2007 â€“ Filed September 18, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Attorney General Henry D.
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy
          Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames,
          all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â 
  Steve R. Bagwell (â€œBagwellâ€) and Daryl Lee Spain (â€œSpainâ€) were convicted by a
  jury of first degree burglary.Â  The judge sentenced Bagwell to twenty years of
  confinement and Spain to fifteen years.Â  Bagwell and Spain appeal their
  convictions alleging the trial judge erred in ruling inadmissible a defense
  witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
In
  September 2003, Jarrett Armstrong (â€œArmstrongâ€) and Chris Snoddy (â€œSnoddyâ€)
  shared an apartment in Greenville County, and both worked at a local Applebeeâ€™s
  restaurant.Â  Bagwell and Spain shared an apartment in the same complex.
On
  September 13, 2003, the day of the burglary, Armstrong worked from 5 p.m. until
  10 p.m.Â  Armstrong testified he went home at 10 p.m., showered, and watched
  television until driving back to Applebeeâ€™s at 11:45 p.m. to pick Snoddy up
  from work.Â  Armstrong waited approximately twenty minutes for Snoddy and left
  with Snoddy around 12:15 a.m. or 12:20 a.m.Â  While en route back to their
  apartment, Armstrong stated he received a call from a neighbor that caused them
  to hurry home.Â  A few neighbors were gathered outside their apartment when
  Armstrong and Snoddy arrived.Â  
Armstrong
  told Snoddy to go around to the rear of the apartment because it appeared
  someone was inside.Â  Armstrong said he entered the apartmentâ€™s front door and
  saw Bagwell, whom Armstrong has known since elementary school, leaving through
  the back glass patio door which had been shattered.Â Â Â  As Bagwell was exiting,
  Armstrong yelled to Snoddy that someone was running out.Â  Armstrong reported
  finding a sandal on the apartment floor that he had seen worn previously by Spain.Â  After checking the upstairs and finding nothing missing, Armstrong went outside to
  check on Snoddy.
Snoddy
  testified that when he arrived at the back of the apartment the glass patio
  door was shattered.Â  Snoddy picked up a metal pole to protect himself.Â  He
  observed Spain exiting the apartment through the shattered door, and he struck Spain with the pole.Â  The two fought until Spain submitted.Â  Spain was not wearing shoes
  and had numerous cuts to his feet.Â  Spain passed out when Armstrong reached the
  back of the apartment.Â  
Armstrong
  and Snoddy then went to Bagwellâ€™s apartment to confront Bagwell.Â  Upon their
  arrival, Bagwell had blood running down his face.Â  Armstrong hit Bagwell one
  time before neighbors intervened.Â  Armstrong called the police.Â  
At
  trial, Spain did not take the stand, but Bagwell testified that he had consumed
  too much alcohol and was home asleep at the time of the incident.Â  
Standard
  of Review
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C.
  520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577,
  575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s
  factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in
  criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v.
    Young, 364 S.C. 476, 613 S.E.2d 386 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The admission of
  evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 207, 631
  S.E.2d 262, 265 (2006); State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d
  87, 93 (2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial
  court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  Pagan,
  369 S.C. at 208, 631 S.E.2d at 265; State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540
  S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  In order for an error of law to warrant reversal, the error must
  result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536
  S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995); State
    v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006).
Discussion
Bagwell
  and Spain argue the trial judge erred in refusing to allow Spainâ€™s brother to testify that Armstrong was angry with Spain because Spain had revealed to a
  mutual neighbor that Armstrong was selling marijuana from his apartment.Â 
  Specifically, Bagwell and Spain claim the statement was admissible under Rule
  608(c), SCRE, to show Armstrongâ€™s bias and motive to fabricate testimony.Â 
  Therefore, Bagwell and Spain contend, the trial judge abused his discretion by
  excluding the evidence under Rule 613, SCRE.Â  
Whether
  the statement was evidence of bias and admissible under Rule 608(c), SCRE, is
  an issue not raised at trial and is thus not preserved for appeal.Â  Pye v.
    Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 633 S.E.2d 505 (2006).Â  See also Staubes
      v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt
  is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal,
  but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved
  for appellate review.â€); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594
  S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting it is axiomatic that an issue cannot be
  raised for the first time on appeal).Â  â€œImposing this preservation requirement
  on the appellant is meant to enable the lower court to rule properly after it
  has considered all relevant facts, law and arguments.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town
    of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000).
The
  State objected to the testimony based on Rule 613(b), SCRE, arguing the defense
  counsel failed to lay a proper foundation for the admissibility of a prior
  inconsistent statement.Â  Under South Carolina law, a proper foundation must be
  laid before admitting a prior inconsistent statement.Â  State v.
    McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 81, 606 S.E.2d 215, 219 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Rule 613(b),
  SCRE, provides:

  Extrinsic
    evidence of a prior inconsistent statement by a witness is not admissible
    unless the witness is advised of the substance of the statement, the time and
    place it was allegedly made, and the person to whom it was made, and is given
    the opportunity to explain or deny the statement.

The
  Solicitor posited, â€œ[T]he appropriate way to [use this statement] would have
  been to ask my victims during cross-examination whether [sic] not they made a
  statement to this man.â€ In response to the Stateâ€™s challenge to the testimony, the
  defense counsel opined to the trial judge, â€œ[T]he foundation is laid.Â  He
  states in court one thing that happens and then he tells my client something
  different that happens.â€Â  The trial judge sustained the Stateâ€™s objection.Â  At
  no time during the trial did Bagwell and Spain assert the testimony would show bias,
  prejudice, or motive for Armstrong and Snoddy to testify falsely.Â  Accordingly,
  the trial judge was never presented with the opportunity to rule whether the evidence
  was admissible under Rule 608(c).
Though
  we find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s ruling, any error arising
  from the exclusion of the evidence in the present case would be harmless. 
Error is harmless where it could not
  reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355
  S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d
  646 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside
  convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v.
    Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354
  S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, an error is harmless where
  guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other
  rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377
  S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795.Â  The
  conviction should not be reversed where a review of the entire record
  establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v.
    Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996); State v. Fletcher, 363
  S.C. 221, 609 S.E.2d 572 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142,
  561 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002).
In State v. Fossick, 333 S.C. 66,
  70, 508 S.E.2d 32, 33-34 (1998), and State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513
  S.E.2d 606 (1999), the supreme court applied a harmless error analysis to the
  failure to allow impeaching testimony.Â Â  In both cases, the court concluded the
  judgeâ€™s error in excluding impeachment evidence was harmless.Â  In Fossick,
  the court explained:

  In determining harmless error regarding
    any issues of witness credibility, we will consider the importance of the
    witnessâ€™s testimony to the prosecutionâ€™s case, whether the witnessâ€™s testimony
    was cumulative, whether other evidence corroborates or contradicts the
    witnessâ€™s testimony, the extent of cross-examination otherwise permitted, and
    the overall strength of the Stateâ€™s case.Â  State v. Holmes, 320 S.C.
    259, 464 S.E.2d 334 (1995) (citing Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 106 S.Ct. 1431, 89 L.Ed2d 674 (1986)).

Id. at 70, 508
  S.E.2d at 34.
Here,
  physical evidence corroborated the testimony of Armstrong and Snoddy and
  provided the State with a strong case.Â  The back glass door of the victimsâ€™
  apartment had been shattered.Â  Armstrong saw Bagwell, whom he had known for
  years, leaving the apartment.Â  Snoddy testified he saw Spain exit the apartment through the broken door, and the two had a physical altercation at
  the scene.Â  Additionally, Armstrong averred the shoe left in his apartment was
  one he remembered Spain wearing.Â  Importantly, both of these statements indicate
  the lacerations to Spainâ€™s feet were caused by the doorâ€™s broken glass. Finally,
  counsel for Bagwell and Spain were permitted to cross-examine Armstrong and
  Snoddy.Â  Accordingly, even if the trial judge had erred in excluding the testimony
  of Spainâ€™s brother, such error was harmless as it could not reasonably have
  affected the outcome of the trial.Â  Â Â Â 
Conclusion
The
  trial judge did not err in ruling inadmissible the defense witnessâ€™s testimony.Â 
  At trial, Bagwell and Spain never argued the evidence was admissible under Rule
  608(c), SCRE.Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â 
  Further, the trial judge properly found no foundation had been laid to admit
  under Rule 613(b), SCRE.Â  Finally, any possible error in its exclusion was
  harmless given the physical evidence and the opportunity for cross-examination
  of Armstrong and Snoddy.Â  Accordingly, Bagwell and Spainâ€™s convictions and
  sentences are 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ., and CURETON,
  A.J., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument
pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â 
  This is an appeal of certain provisions in a divorce decree.Â  Randy Findley
  (Husband) alleges error in the family courtâ€™s decisions on child support,
  equitable distribution, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The
  parties married on May 5, 1995.Â  They have a daughter, who was born
  December 26, 1995.Â  Debora Findley (Wife) has full custody of another daughter
  from a previous marriage.  
The
  parties initially lived in Wifeâ€™s house in Alabama.Â  They later purchased
  property on which they built a home and rented Wifeâ€™s house to Wifeâ€™s brother.Â 
  While they were still in Alabama, Husband filed for divorce; however, the
  parties later reconciled and moved to South Carolina.  
Husband
  and Wife began living separate and apart on or about February 2, 2003.Â  On May
  16, 2003, Wife commenced this action by filing a summons and complaint for
  separate maintenance and support, custody of the partiesâ€™ child, child support,
  alimony, equitable distribution, attorneyâ€™s fees, and other relief.Â  On June
  12, 2003, Husband filed an answer and counterclaim in which he requested, among
  other relief, a divorce on the ground of habitual drunkenness, custody and
  child support, equitable distribution, and attorneyâ€™s fees.
Pursuant
  to motions for temporary relief filed by both parties, the family court held a
  hearing on July 21, 2003, and issued a temporary order on August 10, 2003,
  granting Wife custody of the partiesâ€™ child with visitation to Husband and
  directing Husband to pay alimony of $750.00 per month, child support of $830.00
  per month, and $1,500.00 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees. Â Husband
  unsuccessfully moved for reconsideration of the temporary order. Â Following the
  denial of his motion for reconsideration of the temporary order, Husband
  retained his present counsel and unsuccessfully moved to reduce child support
  and eliminate his alimony obligation.[2] 
 
The final hearing took place on August 4,
  2004.Â  On November 16, 2004, the family court filed a final order in the matter
  (1) granting both parties a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous
  separation, (2) granting Wife custody of the partiesâ€™ child with visitation to
  Husband, (3) continuing the terms of the temporary order in full force and
  effect until the sale of the former marital home, (4) directing Husband to pay
  child support of $788.00 per month and alimony of $300.00 per month beginning
  the first day of the month after the sale of the marital residence and
  continuing on a monthly basis thereafter, (5) directing Wife and provide health
  insurance on the partiesâ€™ child and instructing the parties as to how to divide
  the childâ€™s uncovered medical expenses, (6) dividing the marital assets and
  providing certain instructions as to how a division was to be effected, and (7)
  directing Husband to pay $5,000.00 to Wifeâ€™s attorney.[3]
On or
  about November 17, 2004, Husband moved for reconsideration.Â  On December 1,
  2004, Husband filed an amended motion for reconsideration in which he
  challenged (1) the grant of certain real property to Wife, (2) the inclusion of
  certain allegedly non-marital items in his share of the marital property, (3)
  the valuation of certain items awarded to Wife in the equitable distribution,
  (4) the award of certain items to him for which he had no use and the valuation
  of these items as determined by the family court, (5) certain provisions
  concerning custody, visitation, and child support, (6) the attorneyâ€™s fees
  award, and (7) the alimony award.Â  On December 8, 2004, the family court held a
  hearing on the motions.Â  On January 28, 2005, the family court signed an order
  amending the divorce decree with regard to certain portions of the equitable
  division, visitation, and child support and denying the remaining issues that
  Husband raised in his motions.Â  The order was filed on February 10, 2005, and
  Husband filed his notice of appeal on March 2, 2005.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, an
  appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own
  view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C.
  532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford,
  307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992) and Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543,
  466 S.E.2d 373 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  â€œThis broad scope of review does not,
  however, require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family
  court.â€Â  Id. (citing Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 279
  S.E.2d 616 (1981)).Â  â€œNeither is the appellate court required to ignore the
  fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.â€Â  Id. (citing Cherry Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280
  S.E.2d 541 (1981)).Â  Moreover, â€œwhen an
  appellate court chooses to find facts in accordance with its own view of the
  evidence, the court must state distinctly its findings of fact and the reason
  for its decision.â€Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278,
  283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002) (citing Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.  Husband first
  argues the family court, when computing child support, erred in finding medical
  and dental insurance premiums paid by Wife that were attributable to coverage
  of their child totaled $120.00.Â  We agree the family courtâ€™s initial
  calculations were in error for this reason; however, it appears from the order
  amending the decree the court made the appropriate adjustment.
On her
  child support worksheet, Wife indicated the portion of her monthly health
  insurance premium â€œcovering children onlyâ€ was $120.00.Â  At trial, however,
  Wife admitted on cross examination this amount covered not only the partiesâ€™
  minor child, but also Wifeâ€™s daughter from her prior marriage as well as Wife
  herself.Â  Wife attempted to justify her right to claim the entire amount for
  the partiesâ€™ child by stating (1) although her older child was on her medical
  policy, that child had health insurance provided by her father; and (2)
  â€œdifferent premiumsâ€ would be assessed depending on whether the insured was a
  single person, a person with a spouse, or a person with a family.  
Under
  the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines, the family court â€œshould consider
  provisions for adequate health insurance coverage for children in every child
  support order.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs.114-4720(E) (1992).Â  The guidelines
  further provide â€œthe portion of the health insurance which covers the children
  is the only expense that should be added.â€Â  Id.  
As
  Husband noted in his brief, the family court appeared to dismiss his argument
  that the amount Wife maintained she was paying actually covered, in addition to
  the partiesâ€™ child, Wifeâ€™s older daughter and Wife herself.Â  Nevertheless, in
  the order issued pursuant to his motion, the family court, after referencing
  the previous final child support award of $788.00 per month, ruled that
  â€œ[u]sing revised child support calculations, . . . [Husband] shall commence
  child support payments in the amount of $733.00 per monthâ€ and further noted
  that, regarding child support, the divorce decree was â€œamended to conform with
  my findings of fact set forth hereinabove and [Husband] shall pay child support
  on a monthly basis . . . of $733.00 per month.â€Â  This revised award reflects
  the amount Husband claims should be allotted to insurance coverage for the
  partiesâ€™ child.[4]Â 
  Although the family court appeared to reject Husbandâ€™s position during the
  hearing on his post-trial motion, it is evident from the written order that the
  court ultimately accepted his argument and was within its right to do so.Â  See Christy v. Christy, 354 S.C. 203, 206, 580 S.E.2d 44, 446 (2003) (â€œ â€˜Until the paper has been
  delivered by the judge to the clerk of court, to be filed by him as an order in
  the case, it is subject to the control of the judge, and may be withdrawn at
  any time before such delivery.â€™ â€) (quoting Archer v. Long, 46 S.C. 292,
  295, 24 S.E. 83, 84 (1896)).
2.Â  Husband next
  argues the family court abused its discretion in basing child support on Wifeâ€™s
  claim that childcare costs for the partiesâ€™ child came to $370.00 per month.Â 
  We disagree.
Wife noted
  on her financial declaration that her gross monthly childcare costs were
  $370.00 and used the same figure on her child support worksheet.Â  She
  gave consistent testimony on direct examination about this matter.Â  On cross
  examination, however, she acknowledged her childcare costs for the prior year,
  as reflected on her most recent federal income tax return, averaged to only
  $177.50 per month, suggesting a difference in excess of $1,500.00 per year
  between her childcare costs for the year during which the divorce hearing took
  place and those for the prior year.  
In his
  brief, Husbandâ€™s sole argument is that â€œit defies common sense to believe the
  childcare net of tax credit had increased $1,500 only one year for after school
  and summer childcare.â€Â  In our view, however, the alleged discrepancy only goes
  to the weight of the evidence and is insufficient reason for this Court to hold
  the family court made an incorrect finding regarding work-related childcare
  costs.Â  As Wife notes in her brief, the sole challenge at trial to her evidence
  regarding childcare costs was a brief question from Husbandâ€™s attorney
  regarding her 2003 tax return.Â  Neither party proffered any further testimony or
  evidence concerning work-related childcare costs. Â We therefore hold the family
  court based its decision on the evidence presented and acted within its
  discretion in doing so.[5]Â 
  In so holding, we note Husband should have been able to procure pertinent evidence
  from the childâ€™s caregivers if he considered Wifeâ€™s figures suspect and the
  record does not suggest that he even attempted to do this.
3.Â  Husband next
  argues the family court â€œabused its discretion in adopting the lowest suggested
  sales price in the comparative market analysis of the marital homeâ€ rather than
  the median value suggested by the analysis.Â  In support of this argument,
  Husband further notes the analysis was eight months old at the time of trial
  and therefore artificially low in a rising real estate market.Â  We reject these
  contentions.
Wife testified the
  market analysis she submitted into evidence was the highest of three market
  analyses conducted on the house.Â  Moreover, Husband had ample opportunity to
  seek his own appraisal and, although he filed a motion to have another
  appraisal, he never followed through with it.Â  Based on the evidence before us,
  we find the family courtâ€™s determination of the value of the marital residence
  was within its discretion.Â  See Noll v. Noll, 297 S.C. 190, 194,
  375 S.E.2d 338, 340-41 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œIn the absence
  of contrary evidence, the court should accept the value the
  parties assign to a marital asset.â€).
4.Â  Husband next
  complains the family court should not have required him to continue paying
  child support and alimony at the levels set by the temporary order for an
  additional thirty days given to Wife to refinance the marital home and buy out
  Husbandâ€™s equity.Â  In support of this argument, Husband argues Wife had ample
  time before the hearing to arrange refinancing and admitted she had initially
  received approval without relying on spousal support. Â In his reply brief,
  Husband further argues the alleged error was compounded by the fact that Wifeâ€™s
  attorney delayed submission of the final order for three months, thus enabling
  her to receive four months of child and spousal support at the higher levels.[6]Â  We find no reversible error.Â  Husband
  should have raised these concerns in his post-trial motion to enable the family
  court to address them; however, this he failed to do.Â  Because, therefore, the
  family court did not have the opportunity to rule on this issue, we hold it was
  not preserved for our review.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding the court of appeals improperly addressed an issue that the
  â€œcircuit court did not explicitly rule onâ€ when the appellant did not raise the
  issue in a motion to alter or amend).
5.Â  Husband next
  submits the alimony awarded to Wife should be reversed in view of (1) Wifeâ€™s
  misconduct during the marriage, (2) Wifeâ€™s level of education, (3) the
  equitable distribution Wife received in the divorce, (4) Wifeâ€™s contributions
  to the marriage, (5) the length of the marriage, and (6) the allegation that,
  when Wifeâ€™s child support was considered, Wifehad more income than did Husband.[7]Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  See Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 292, 617 S.E.2d 359, 362 (2005) (â€œAn award
  of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not
  be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€).
Although
  Wife had completed more schooling than did Husband and was working as an
  insurance agent at the time of the divorce hearing, it was undisputed that she
  consistently earned less than he did throughout the marriage.Â  Moreover, we
  agree with the family court that any support Wife was receiving for her older
  child should not be considered as income belonging to her for purposes of
  determining her eligibility for alimony because, as the family court noted,
  â€œ[s]he has the obligation to contribute, as well as the father.â€Â  Similar logic
  can be applied to the child support awarded for the child of the marriage. Â As
  to Wifeâ€™s alleged misconduct, we find it significant that the family court
  expressly found â€œthe fault allegations set forth in the partiesâ€™ pleadings was
  not supported by sufficient evidenceâ€ and chose instead to grant the divorce to
  both parties on the ground of a one-year separation.Â  Although there may reason
  to differ with the weight the family court gave to each of the statutory
  factors for alimony, the concerns Husband has raised in this appeal do not
  warrant the reduction or setting aside of the alimony award.Â  See Doe
    v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 504-05, 478 S.E.2d 854, 860 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting
  â€œ[n]o one factor is considered dispositiveâ€ in determining an award of spousal
  support).
6.Â  Husband next argues the
  attorneyâ€™s fees award to Wife should be reduced or eliminated altogether,
  citing among other reasons (1) fees assessed him after the temporary hearing, (2)
  Wifeâ€™s ability to pay her own attorney as compared with his own financial
  circumstances, (3) the fact that Husband did not pursue his counterclaim for
  custody, (4) deficiencies in the representation provided by Wifeâ€™s attorney,
  and (5) dilatory tactics allegedly used by Wifeâ€™s attorney to prolong the
  period that Husband had to pay higher levels of child and spousal support.Â  We
  find no abuse of discretion based on any of these grounds to justify reversing
  or modifying the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded to Wife.Â  In our view, the family
  court adequately considered the requisite factors under Glasscock v.
    Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991), in determining
  the amount to award Wife as attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In particular, we note the
  difficulty of the case was exacerbated by numerous motions filed by Husband
  while the lawsuit was pending, thus increasing the time Wifeâ€™s attorney had to
  devote to the matter.Â  Moreover, Wife was the prevailing party on most, if not
  all, matters at trial.Â Â   
7.Â  We reject Husbandâ€™s
  contention that the family court should have awarded him a special equity in
  Wifeâ€™s pre-marital home.Â  Contrary to Husbandâ€™s argument that he presented
  â€œuncontroverted testimonyâ€ that marital funds were used to pay the mortgage on
  the home as well as for a new roof, a front porch, a carport, new carpeting,
  and a heating system, Wife testified that she made the mortgage payments, no
  new carpet was installed, no new porch was built, and the new heating was not a
  â€œheating systemâ€ but simply propane models that hung on the wall.Â  As to the
  roof, Wife testified her brother, who worked as a roofer, installed a partial
  new roof after a hail storm.Â  Because there was conflicting testimony regarding
  Husbandâ€™s entitlement to a special equity in Wifeâ€™s pre-marital residence, we
  defer to the family courtâ€™s decision on this matter.Â  See Murdock v.
    Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 245 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting
  that, although the court of appeals has jurisdiction in family law cases to
  find facts according to its own view of the evidence, it is not required to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings or â€œto ignore the fact that the family
  court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to
  evaluate their testimonyâ€).
8.Â  We reject Husbandâ€™s
  argument that the family court abused its discretion in allegedly â€œadopting
  wholesaleâ€ personal property valuations that Wife or her attorney allegedly â€œhurriedly
  jotted on [Husbandâ€™s] marital assets addendum during a break at trial.â€ No
  proof of value was offered by either party other than their opinions regarding
  the worth of the various items.Â  Moreover, in support of his position, Husband
  alleges on appeal that Wifeâ€™s valuations were â€œlow-balledâ€ without directing
  our attention to any evidence showing how they were incorrect.Â  Without any
  specific assignments of error, we see no reason to disturb the family courtâ€™s
  assessments of worth for the various items at issue.Â   
9.Â  Finally,
  Husband alleges the family court erred in awarding him various personal effects
  for which he allegedly had no use.Â  He further maintains the error is
  compounded by Wifeâ€™s claim that she did not to know where the items were
  located, the fact that he was presently living out-of-state in a rented room,
  and his allegation that the family court gave the items artificially high
  values.Â  We find no merit to these assertions.
According
  to Husbandâ€™s brief, the items at issue consisted of a rug, a plant, a
  non-working computer, discs, a VHS player, an antique curio cabinet, a floral
  picture, a telephone, carving knives, pots, pans, and corning ware.Â  The only
  item of any significant worth or bulk was the curio cabinet, which the family
  court assessed at $500.00.Â  The family court specifically found this item was a
  non-marital asset and Husband does not appeal this finding; therefore, we
  affirm the decision to award it in-kind to Husband.Â  See S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2006) (â€œThe [family] court does not have jurisdiction or
  authority to apportion nonmarital property.â€).
Several of the items that Husband claims he received in the
  equitable division but did not want were assigned no value at all; these
  consisted of the rug, the computer and disks, the telephone and the pots and
  pans. Â Because these items were assessed a zero value, Husbandâ€™s claim
  that they resulted in Wifeâ€™s receiving a â€œmonetary offsetâ€ for them lacks merit.
  Â 
The total value assigned by the family court to the remaining
  items in question was $87.50.Â  Ironically, however, in his post-trial motion,
  Husband requested not only that these items be awarded in-kind to Wife, he
  alleged they had been â€œgrossly undervaluedâ€ when they were included in the inventory
  of property that the family court awarded to him.Â  Under these circumstances,
  we are at a loss to see how Husband can now complain the family court assigned
  inflated values to these items.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The record contains a rule to show cause against
  Husband issued April 19, 2004, after the denial of Husbandâ€™s motion to reduce
  child support and eliminate alimony.Â  In Wifeâ€™s verified petition, she alleges
  Husband had failed to pay these obligations in a timely manner and was in arrears.Â 
  Although the rule to show cause noted a hearing was scheduled for June 15,
  2004, the record does not indicate the outcome of the hearing.
[3]Â  The final order reproduced in the record appears to
  stop in mid-sentence and the summary given above is based on the portion that
  was made available.Â  The clerkâ€™s file has a complete copy of the order; all
  that is missing is the final page, which has only about one-half page of text
  and information that does not affect this appeal.
[4]Â  In addition to the dispute regarding the cost of
  medical insurance on the partiesâ€™ child, Husband alleged in his post-trial
  motion that Wife underreported her income and presented a grossly inflated
  figure for the cost of her work-related childcare.Â  From our reading of the
  written order issued by the family court after it heard the motion, it appears
  the family court accepted the figures that Husband suggested correctly
  reflected Wifeâ€™s monthly gross income and health insurance premiums for the
  partiesâ€™ child and rejected the figure he proposed for work-related childcare.Â 
  We calculated child support using the worksheet that Husband included as an
  exhibit with his motion, which appears on page 93 of the record on appeal.Â  In
  our calculations, we used the revised figure for Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income
  and the figure Husband claimed reflected the correct cost of health insurance
  premiums for the partiesâ€™ child; however, we used the figure for work-related
  childcare that the family court had applied when initially setting child
  support instead of the figure Husband suggested on the worksheet.Â  Using
  the revised figures suggested by Husband for both Wifeâ€™s income and health
  insurance premiums for the child, we computed child support under the
  guidelines to be $732.09 per month, which deviates from the family courtâ€™s
  calculation by less than $1.00 per month.  
[5]Â  On her financial declaration, Wife notes the $370.00
  per month she was claiming for childcare â€œincludes dance & swim lessons.â€Â 
  The costs of these lessons could possibly account for the large discrepancy about
  which Husband was complaining; however, we have found nothing in the record
  indicating either party advanced this theory at trial.
[6]Â  As noted in the facts, the temporary order set
  alimony and child support at $750.00 per month and $830.00 per month,
  respectively.Â  In the final order, the family court set alimony at $300.00 per
  month and child support at $788.00 per month, but later reduced child support
  to $733.00 per month.
[7]Â  During trial, Husband alleged that Wife was unfaithful and extravagant.Â  He further maintained she abused alcohol and did not contribute financially
  to the marriage in a level befitting her education and other circumstances.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jim Payne, Appellant,
				v.
				Kelly Payne, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-383
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  September 20, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Jean Perrin Derrick, of Lexington, for Appellant.
				Henry H. Taylor, of West Columbia, Katherine Carruth Link, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this family law action, Jim Payne (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s holding
  that it lacked jurisdiction to modify alimony payments.Â  The family court based
  its ruling on the language in the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement, which it found
  was clear, unequivocal, and unambiguous in stating that the agreement shall not
  be modified, altered, or amended by the family court.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Kelly Payne (Wife) and Husband married in February 1992. Â The parties
  have three children. Â In May 2000, the parties separated and reached a
  comprehensive support and property settlement agreement.Â  That agreement was
  incorporated into the family courtâ€™s order, issued in December 2000, regarding
  the initial action for separate support and maintenance.Â  The final order of
  divorce approved the settlement agreement and incorporated it into the divorce
  decree in January 2003.Â   
The present action arises from Husbandâ€™s motion to terminate or
  reduce his monthly alimony obligation.Â  Wife argued the settlement agreement
  was not modifiable by the family court.Â  Wife filed a motion to dismiss
  Husbandâ€™s action pursuant to the modification language in the settlement
  agreement.Â  Â The family court granted Wifeâ€™s motion to dismiss, finding the
  language of the settlement agreement divested the court of subject matter
  jurisdiction to modify the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â   
Husband filed a motion to reconsider, which the family court
  denied. Â Â This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from
  the family court, this Court may
  find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence. Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369
  (2002).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â 
  Our broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of his burden to
  convince this Court the family court committed error.Â  Skinner
    v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in holding it lacked subject
  matter jurisdiction to modify the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement.Â  Husband also asserts
  the family court erred in ignoring the doctrines of merger and law of the
  case.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Alimony
  Modification
Questions concerning alimony rest within the sound discretion of
  the family court judge, whose conclusions will not be disturbed in the absence
  of an abuse of that discretion.Â  Stoddard v. Riddle, 362 S.C. 266, 268,
  607 S.E.2d 97, 98 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the family
  courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on findings of
  fact having no evidentiary support.Â  Id.Â   
The family court has the authority to modify alimony agreements
  â€œunless the agreement unambiguously denies the court jurisdictionâ€ to do so.Â  Moseley
    v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 353, 306 S.E.2d 624, 627 (1983).Â  â€œ[O]nce an
  alimony agreement that specifically disallows modification is approved by the court
  and merged into a judicial order, it is binding on the parties and the court
  and is not subject to modification.â€Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C.
  497, 500-01, 602 S.E.2d 96, 98 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The parties may specifically â€œagree
  that the amount of alimony may not ever be modified by the court.â€Â  Croom v.
    Croom, 305 S.C. 158, 161, 406 S.E.2d 381, 383 (Ct. App. 1991).

	The partiesâ€™ agreement reads, in pertinent part:
	EFFECTS OF DIVORCE
	12.Â  . . .Â  This Agreement shall be offered in evidence in such
  action and if acceptable to the [c]ourt, shall be incorporated by reference
  into any Decree of Divorce that may be granted therein; provided, however, that
  not withstanding such incorporation, this Agreement shall not be modified,
  altered or amended by the [c]ourt, but shall be binding and conclusive as to
  those matters covered herein on the parties forever.
	. . .
	APPROVAL
	16.Â  This Agreement shall be submitted to the [f]amily [c]ourt for
  the State of South Carolina for the purpose of having the [c]ourt review,
  approve and merge the terms and conditions of this Agreement and for the
  issuance of an appropriate Order approving the terms and conditions hereof and
  making the same the Order of the Court, and merging this Agreement with such
  Order.Â  The parties agree and acknowledge that this is a fully integrated and
  complete Separation Agreement with respect to all matters raised or those which
  could have been raised in the controversies between them.

In Moseley,
  our Supreme Court adopted a rule allowing parties to specifically agree that
  the court may never modify the terms of their agreement.Â  This decision acknowledged
  that the parties could contract out of the family courtâ€™s continuing
  jurisdictional supervision of their relationship.Â  Moseley, 279 S.C. at
  353, 306 S.E.2d at 627.Â   
Furthermore,
  in Degenhart, this Court honored a settlement agreement which did not
  explicitly state the family court was devoid of jurisdiction to modify the
  alimony agreement, but rather it said the only way to modify the agreement was
  with the written consent of the parties.Â  We specifically stated there would be
  no requirement of â€œâ€˜magic wordsâ€™ for an unambiguous agreement to gain
  efficacy.â€ Degenhart 360 S.C. at 501, 602 S.E.2d at 98. Â Therefore, this
  Court found the partiesâ€™ agreement non-modifiable.Â  Id.
The
  family court relied on Moseley and Degenhart in arriving at its
  decision that the agreement in this case denied it jurisdiction to modify
  alimony.Â  The family court found the language in the agreement was clear,
  unequivocal, and unambiguous in denying it the ability to modify the terms of
  the agreement.Â  Our review of the record and the applicable case law leads us
  to the same conclusion.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not err in
  holding it lacked jurisdiction to modify the terms of the alimony agreement.
II.Â  Merger
Husband argues the concept of merger gives
  the family court jurisdiction to modify the terms of the agreement, which was
  adopted into the courtâ€™s order.Â  We disagree.
Merger is
  a word of art meaning â€œ1. The act or an instance of combining or uniting. 2. [Contracts]
  The substitution of a superior form of contract for an inferior form, as when a
  written contract supersedes all oral agreements and prior understandings.â€ Blackâ€™s law dictionary 1002 (7th ed. 1999).Â  When an agreement
  is merged into a courtâ€™s decree, that decree â€œshould be construed to effect the
  intent of both the judge and the parties.â€Â  Messer v. Messer, 359 S.C.
  614, 628, 598 S.E.2d 310, 318 (Ct. App. 2004).Â   
Traditionally,
  the family court was devoid of jurisdiction to modify agreements which were not
  merged into a court order.Â  Kelly v. Edwards, 276 S.C. 368, 369, 278
  S.E.2d 773, 773-74 (1981).Â  However, the decision in Moseley â€œattempt[ed] to eliminate the words of art [such as merger] from domestic
  law.â€Â  Moseley 279 S.C. at 353, 306 S.E.2d at 627.Â  Thus, the current
  state of the law is that words of art will not govern jurisdiction, but rather
  the intent of the parties and the clear, unambiguous language of the agreement
  will be honored by the court.Â  Id. at 352-53, 306 S.E.2d at 627; see Maxwell v. Maxwell, Op. No. 4290, --- S.C. ----, --- S.E.2d ----, 2007
  WL 2415733 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œWhile the family court normally has the authority
  to modify alimony, once an alimony agreement that specifically disallows
  modification is approved by the court and merged into a judicial order, it is
  binding on the parties and the court and is not subject to
  modification.â€)(internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  Therefore, we hold
  the family court did not err in finding it lacked jurisdiction to modify the
  alimony provisions of the partiesâ€™ agreement even though the language called
  for merger of that agreement into a court order.
III. Law of
  the Case
Husband
  argues the agreement is modifiable pursuant to the law of the case.Â  We
  disagree.
Law of the case refers to the idea that the terms of orders which
  are not appealed become the law of the case regardless of whether those terms
  are legally correct. Â McAleese v. McAleese, 309 S.C. 548, 551, 424
  S.E.2d 558, 559-60 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Husband cites to an October 2002 order
  resulting from a rule to show cause. Â The family court approved an agreement of
  the parties requiring Husband to pay alimony and child support arrearages in a
  lump sum and to continue his regular payments.Â  Husband relies on part of the
  October order which states, â€œ[Husband] will pay [Wife] $3500 per month pursuant
  to the agreement until or unless the amount is modified by a court of competent
  jurisdiction.â€Â  Neither the agreement nor the order of the court, however,
  altered the terms of the monthly payments or the provision that disallowed the
  court to modify the alimony.Â   
Subsequent to the contempt order of October 2002, the parties
  divorced in January 2003 and the prior order from December 2000, which prohibited
  the modification of alimony, was incorporated in the Divorce Decree. Â Â 
Pursuant to the original order, the family court had jurisdiction
  to enforce the alimony and child support payments through its contempt powers.Â 
  The agreement in the December 2000 order, which was subsequently incorporated
  in the January 2003 Divorce Decree, is clear and specific that the alimony is
  not modifiable by the court.Â  The agreement states:

	12.Â  . . .Â  This Agreement shall be offered in evidence in such
  action and if acceptable to the [c]ourt, shall be incorporated by reference
  into any Decree of Divorce that may be granted therein; provided, however, that
  not withstanding such incorporation, this Agreement shall not be modified,
  altered or amended by the [c]ourt, but shall be binding and conclusive as to
  those matters covered herein on the parties forever.

Although in the absence of this agreement the family court would
  have had jurisdiction to modify the alimony payments, â€œonce an alimony
  agreement that specifically disallows modification is approved by the court and
  merged into a judicial order, it is binding on the parties and the court and is
  not subject to modification.â€Â  Degenhart, 360 S.C. at 500-01, 602 S.E.2d
  at 98.Â  Therefore, once this agreement was merged into the Divorce Decree the
  family court no longer had jurisdiction to modify it. The contempt order of
  October 2002 did not attempt to modify the alimony agreement, it merely recited
  the total past due amount of alimony and child support.Â  The order made no
  reference that the prior agreement was being changed to allow future
  modification of alimony by the court.Â   
The partiesâ€™ agreement is clear and unambiguous.Â  The terms of
  that agreement deny the family court jurisdiction to modify Husbandâ€™s alimony
  payments.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in holding it lacked
  jurisdiction to alter Husbandâ€™s alimony payments.Â   
Accordingly, the
  family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[1]
STILWELL, SHORT,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Regina Miller, Plaintiff,
				v.
				The Unity Group
      Inc. Modern Business, Continental Casualty Insurance Company, and SCUEF, Defendants,
				of whom The
      Unity Group Inc. Modern Business is the Respondent,
				and Continental
      Casualty Insurance Company is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-384
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed September 20,
  2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Andrew D. Smith, Trask & Howell, LLC, of Mt. Pleasant, for
  Appellant.
				Nate Fata, Nate Fata, PA, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Modern Business Associates (MBA) maintains workersâ€™
  compensation insurance coverage through Continental Casualty Insurance Company
  (Continental).Â  The trial court concluded Unity Group was also a named insured
  under this policy.Â  Continental appeals and we affirm.Â   
FACTS
This case arises out of workersâ€™ compensation claims
  made by Regina Miller.Â  Miller claims she suffered compensable injuries that
  arose during the scope of employment in March and July of 2002.Â  When the March
  incident occurred, Unity Group had acquired Millerâ€™s services through
  Multistaff Leasing Company (Multistaff).Â   
Unity Group is a
  hotel housekeeping company that services hotels in the Myrtle Beach area.Â 
  Unity Group had an agreement with Multistaff, which stated the latter would
  provide temporary employees, such as Miller, to Unity Group.Â  Shortly after the
  March episode, but prior to the July accident, Unity Group ended its
  relationship with Multistaff and contracted with MBA to provide leasing
  services.Â   
The contract
  between MBA and Unity Group required MBA to maintain workersâ€™ compensation
  insurance coverage.Â  MBAâ€™s insurance provider was Continental.Â  In late April
  2002, Unity Group received a Certificate of Liability Insurance (the
  Certificate) prepared by Continentalâ€™s agent.Â   
The Certificate lists
  Unity Group as a â€œCertificate Holder Additional Insured.â€Â  Based on the Certificate,
  Unity Group argues it is insured under MBAâ€™s contract of insurance with
  Continental.Â  Unity Group also argues Continentalâ€™s decision to appeal the
  trial courtâ€™s ruling that Unity Group is an insured is an interlocutory appeal,
  and therefore, not immediately appealable.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When the purpose of the dispute is to determine whether a party is
  an insured under an insurance policy, we will correct errors of law, but
  factual findings of the trial court will not be disturbed unless unsupported by
  any evidence.Â  See Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. James, 337 S.C. 
86, 93, 522 S.E.2d 345, 348-49 (Ct. App. 1999) (In a suit to determine coverage 
under an automobile liability policy, an appellate courtâ€™s standard of review is 
limited to correcting errors of law.  Factual findings of the trial court 
will not be disturbed, unless found to be without evidence which reasonably 
supports the judgeâ€™s findings.).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Interlocutory appeal
Unity
  Group initially argues this Court lacks jurisdiction to decide this case
  because this appeal constitutes an interlocutory appeal.Â  We disagree.
Generally,
  an appeal to this Court will be allowed only if the trial court has issued a
  final judgment.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 194, 607 S.E.2d
  707, 708 (2005).Â  However, the following four situations permit a party to appeal
  absent a final judgment:  

	(1)
  intermediate judgments, orders or decrees involving the merits, (2) orders
  affecting substantial rights when such orders in effect determine the action
  and prevent a judgment from which an appeal may be taken or when the orders
  discontinue the action, (3) a final order in special proceedings, and (4)
  interlocutory orders [relating to injunctions].

Â Walker v. Springs
  Indus., Inc., 298 S.C. 249, 251, 379 S.E.2d 729, 730 (Ct. App. 1989).
Â â€œAn order involves the merits if it
  finally determines some substantial matter forming the whole or part of some
  cause of action or defense in the case.â€Â  Green v. City of Columbia, 311
  S.C. 78, 80, 427 S.E.2d 685, 687 (Ct. App. 1993).
The determination
  of whether Unity Group is a named insured involves the merits of the case.Â  If
  Unity Group is not an insured, then Continental does not owe a duty to defend
  Unity Group in the underlying action.Â  Conversely, if Unity Group is deemed a
  named insured under MBAâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation policy, then Continental owes a
  duty to defend Unity Group.Â  Thus, the determination of Unity Groupâ€™s status
  with respect to Continental is dispositive of whether Continental owes a duty
  to defend Unity Group.  
Having
  determined this appeal is properly before us, we now turn our attention to
  whether Unity Group is a named insured.
B. Unity Group is a named
  insured
The
  terms of an insurance policy must be construed liberally in favor of the
  insured.Â  Quinn v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 238 S.C. 301, 304,
  120 S.E.2d 15, 16 (1961).Â  Insurance policies are subject to the common rules
  of contract construction.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, in the absence of ambiguity,
  the terms of the policy will be given their plain, ordinary, and popular
  meaning.Â  Id.Â  However, when the terms of the policy are capable of two
  reasonable interpretations, the ambiguity will be resolved in favor of the
  insured.Â  Id. Â Â 
The workersâ€™
  compensation policy between Continental and MBA covers the dates August 1, 2001
  thru August 1, 2002.Â  This policy contains an Alternate Employer Endorsement
  (the Endorsement).Â  The Endorsement states that workersâ€™ compensation insurance
  will apply if an employee of MBA is injured â€œin the course of special or
  temporary employment by the alternate employer . . . .â€[1]Â  Thus, the question becomes whether Unity Group can be considered
  an â€œalternate employer.â€
Neither
  the policy nor the Endorsement defines the term â€œalternate employer.â€Â  Unity
  Group may or may not be an â€œalternate employer.â€Â  We hold that the Endorsement
  creates an ambiguity of whether Unity Group qualifies as an â€œalternate
  employer.â€Â  Under South Carolina law, the ambiguity will be resolved in favor
  of the insured.Â  Id.Â  Thus, Unity Group is an insured under the workersâ€™ compensation policy between MBA and
  Continental. Â This conclusion is supported by the Certificate presented to
  Unity Group by Continentalâ€™s agent.Â   
On
  April 26, 2002, an authorized representative for Continental presented the
  Certificate to Unity Group.Â  Although the Certificate is not part of the insurance
  policy between MBA and Continental, it clarifies the ambiguity created by the
  Endorsement.Â  The Certificate references the workersâ€™ compensation policy
  between MBA and Continental.Â  It states, â€œCoverage is provided for only those
  employees leased to but not subcontractors of: The Unity Group, Inc.â€Â  Moreover,
  Unity Group is listed as the certificate holder and an additional insured.Â  The
  Certificate specifically references the Endorsement.Â  Thus, the Certificate
  presented by Continentalâ€™s agent and the ambiguity created by the Endorsement support
  the conclusion that Unity Group is an insured.  
Finally,
  we note the stated issue on appeal is not the real controversy involved in this
  case.Â  Miller had two accidents,
  one occurring in July 2002, during the time Continentalâ€™s policy was in full
  force and effect, and one occurring in March 2002.Â  The crux of the issue is
  not whether Continental provides coverage for Unity Group, but whether
  Continental owes a duty to Unity Group with respect to Millerâ€™s March
  accident.Â  In the proceedings below, it has so far been determined that the
  injuries suffered by Miller are the result of the first accident.Â 
  Consequently, Unity Group is aggrieved because apparently through no fault of
  its own, it had no workersâ€™ compensation coverage at that time.Â   
The discreet
  question we are asked is stated as follows:Â  â€œDid the Circuit Court err as a
  matter of law in finding that the Unity Group is an insured under Modern
  Business Associatesâ€™ policy of insurance with Continental Casualty Insurance
  Company, who is entitled to defense from Continental Casualty Insurance
  Company?â€Â  This opinion correctly answers that question.Â  However, we have not
  been asked to determine if Unity Â Group provides coverage for the injuries
  suffered by Miller as a result of the first accident, and we are therefore
  precluded from addressing that issue.Â  As former Chief Judge Sanders so aptly
  observed, â€œappellate courts in this state, like well-behaved children, do not
  speak unless spoken to and do not answer questions they are not asked.â€Â  Langley
    v. Boyter, 284 S.C. 162, 182, 325 S.E.2d 550, 561 (Ct. App. 1984), quashed
      on other grounds by 286 S.C. 85, 332 S.E.2d 100 (1985); see Gold
        Kist, Inc. v. Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank of S.C., 286 S.C. 272, 276, 333
  S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding issues not raised in the briefs are
  deemed abandoned).Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Counsel for Continental argues the Endorsement is
  inapplicable because it does not cover the period of August 1, 2001 to August
  1, 2002.Â  We find this argument unpersuasive.Â  The policy between MBA and
  Continental covers the period August 1, 2001 to August 1, 2002.Â  The
  Endorsement lists the policy period as â€œ08/01/01 [to] 08/01/02.â€Â  Thus, the
  Endorsement is part of the insurance policy.Â Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
