THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Michael
      Collins, Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Dodson Brothers
      Exterminating Company, Employer; and Birmingham Fire Insurance Company,
      Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-388
Heard September 12, 2007 â€“ Filed September
  24, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				E. Ros Huff, Jr., of Irmo, for Appellants.
				Craig A. Snook, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this workersâ€™ compensation action, Dodson Brothers Exterminating Company and Birmingham Fire
  Insurance Company (collectively Dodson) appeal the finding of the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commissionâ€™s Appellate Panel that Michael Collins was permanently
  and totally disabled.Â  We affirm.

FACTS
Collins worked at Dodson as a manager.Â  On October 16, 1996, Collinsâ€™s supervisor, Jim Vaughn, told Collins to
  dispose of a pest control product called Phostoxin by dissolving it in a
  bucket of water.Â  When Collins did this, a chemical reaction occurred,
  converting the Phostoxin into a gas, which Collins accidentally inhaled.Â  Shortly
  thereafter, Collins began to experience health problems.Â  Ultimately, following
  a MRI, Dr. Jerry Schexnayder diagnosed Collins with avascular necrosis, a
  disease where the bone experiences a loss of blood supply resulting in bone
  tissue dying and eventually collapsing.Â  Â Â Â Â 
In 1998, Collins had his left hip replaced.Â  In a report dated
  February 7, 2001, Dr. Schexnayder found Collins achieved maximum medical
  improvement for his left hip and gave him a seventy-five percent impairment
  rating for the lower left extremity.Â  On December 4, 2001, Dr. Schexnayder also
  replaced Collinsâ€™s right hip.Â  In a report dated April 15, 2002, Dr. Schexnayer
  determined Collins was at maximum medical improvement for his right hip and
  gave him a seventy-five percent impairment rating for his lower right
  extremity.Â   
On
  August 24, 2000, Collins initially filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim alleging
  he was totally and permanently disabled as a result of inhaling the Phostoxin
  gas.Â  On December 9, 2003, the single commissioner held a hearing on the matter
  and determined Collins was permanently and totally disabled.Â  Dodson appealed,
  and the Appellate Panel affirmed the single commissioner and adopted the single
  commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Dodson appealed, and
  the circuit court affirmed the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal
  followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

The South
  Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for
  judicial review of decisions by the Appellate Panel.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc.,
  276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not
  substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the
  evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected
  by an error of law.Â  Stone v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 274,
  600 S.E.2d 551, 552 (Ct. App. 2004).
The substantial evidence rule governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™
  compensation decision.Â  Frame v.
    Resort Servs. Inc.,357 S.C.
  520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by
  substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct.
  App. 2005). Â An appellate court can reverse or modify the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been
  prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is â€œclearly
  erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the
  whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84
  (Ct. App. 2004).  

	â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order
  to justify its action.


Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306.

â€œ[T]he
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial
  evidence.â€Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C.
  430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984). Â In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the
  Appellate Panel is the ultimate finder of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  Where the evidence is conflicting over a factual issue, the
  findings of the Appellate Panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co.,360 S.C. 276, 290, 599 S.E.2d 604, 611 (Ct. App.
  2004).

LAW/ANALYSIS

Dodson argues
  Collins failed to show by substantial evidence he is permanently and totally disabled
  under section 42-9-10 of the South Carolina Code Â (Supp. 2006).[1]Â 
  We disagree.
Under section 42-9-10, a claimant has three ways to obtain
  total disability.Â  First, a claimant can be presumptively disabled.Â Â   

	The list of injuries included in the presumptive total
  disability category include: â€œ[t]he loss of both hands, arms, feet, legs, or
  vision in both eyes, or any two thereof, constitutes total and permanent
  disability to be compensated according to the provisions of this sectionâ€ or
  that claimant â€œis a paraplegic, a quadriplegic, or who has suffered physical
  brain damage. . . .â€

Wigfall
  v. Tideland Utils., Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 105 n.4, 580 S.E.2d 100, 102 n.4 (2003)
  (quoting Â§ 42-9-10) (alteration and omission by court).Â  For these
  injuries, a claimant need not show a loss of earning capacity because the loss
  is conclusively presumed.Â  Id. at 105, 580 S.E.2d at 102. Â Second, a
  claimant can show an injury that is not a scheduled injury under section
  42-9-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) â€œcaused sufficient loss of
  earning capacity to render him totally disabled.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThird, a
  claimant may establish total disability through multiple physical injuries.â€ Â Id.
First, although Collinsâ€™s doctor gave a seventy-five
  percent impairment rating on each of his legs, Dodson contends Collins does not
  qualify for permanent and total disability without demonstrating a loss of
  earning capacity because Collinsâ€™s injuries were to his hips.[2]Â 
  Further, Dodson contends Collins did not demonstrate a loss of earning capacity.Â 
  We find the record contains substantial evidence Collins sustained a loss of
  earning capacity. Â Accordingly, we need not address whether he was
  presumptively disabled.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of
    Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an
  appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a
  prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
The hips are not a
  part of the leg; they are part of the pelvis.Â  Gilliam v. Woodside Mills,
  319 S.C. 385, 387, 461 S.E.2d 818, 819 (1996).Â  Thus, Collinsâ€™s injuries are
  unscheduled under section 42-9-30.Â  South Carolina jurisprudence provides a
  claimantâ€™s â€œbare statement that he is unable to work
  is insufficient, in our opinion, to afford reasonable basis for the conclusion
  that he is totally disabled,â€ where doctors testify to the contrary. Â Wynn v. Peoples Natural
    Gas Co. of S.C., 238 S.C. 1, 13, 118
  S.E.2d 812, 818 (1961). Â However, in deciding
  whether substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings, we
  consider both the lay and expert evidence. Â Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health
    Care of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 341, 513 S.E.2d 843, 847 (1999).Â  Â While this court has
  previously found reasonable efforts to obtain employment and the testimony of a
  vocational expert are methods of demonstrating a loss of earning capacity, they
  are not the exclusive ways to prove the loss.Â  See Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. # 7, 341 S.C. 580, 588, 535 S.E.2d 146, 150 (Ct. App. 2000); McCollum
    v. Singer Co.,300 S.C. 103, 107,
  386 S.E.2d 471, 474 (Ct. App. 1989), Floyd v. City of Charleston, 287 S.C. 474, 480, 339 S.E.2d 166, 169 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  In Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 384, 335 S.E.2d 91, 95 (Ct. App. 1985), although a doctor testified the claimant could perform jobs
  requiring minimum physical activity such as bricklaying, the doctorâ€™s medical
  report following examination of the claimant stated the claimant became out of
  breath carrying out the garbage or taking a bath.Â  Further, the claimant
  himself testified to continual shortness of breath and tightness in his chest.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, another doctor testified that in his opinion, Hanks
  was permanently and totally disabled. Â Id.Â  This court found substantial evidence supported the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s determination that the claimant was totally disabled based on
  the second doctorâ€™s testimony and the testimony of the claimant. Â Id.
In
  the present case, Collins stopped working at Dodson in 1998 when he first had
  hip replacement surgery, and according to him, he continues to be unable to
  work.Â  He testified he could not get up after squatting and has difficulty
  walking.Â  He testified the pain in his knees and legs prevented him from working.Â 
  Further, Collinsâ€™s doctor, Dr. Schexnayder, twice provided his opinion that
  Collins could not work.Â  In 1999, Dr. Schexnayder stated â€œthis patient is
  totally disabled from performing any occupation at this point.â€Â  In 2001, Dr. Schexnayder
  again stated, â€œ[Collins] currently is unable to perform any gainful employment
  and I am not optimistic that this will change in the future.â€Â  Dodson presented
  no evidence Collins was able to work.Â   
Collins
  had a general equivalency degree and was fifty years old when he testified
  before the single commissioner in 2003.Â  He received no special training after
  school, and he had previously worked as a mechanic for thirteen years and prior
  to that, as a manual laborer.Â  Even though Collinsâ€™s job titles at Dodson were
  sales and then management, those jobs still entailed crawling under houses.Â 
  Collins also testified he was not a great reader and had difficulty balancing
  his checkbook.Â  Given Collinsâ€™s background, the fact he had both hips replaced,
  and his impairment of seventy-five percent to each leg, he does not seem a
  likely candidate for anything that does not involve some physical activity, and
  the record supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding of total and permanent
  disability.Â  We note â€œthe final determination of
  witness credibility and the weight to
  be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel.â€Â  Bass v. Kenco Group,366 S.C. 450, 458, 622 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  Therefore, we find the evidence sufficient to uphold the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s finding Collins permanently and totally disabled.

Further, Collins has
  been found eligible for social security disability and Dodsonâ€™s disability
  insurance program. Â While we are cognizant of the fact â€œawards and records of the Social Security Administration ordinarily cannot be relied upon to support or deny a workersâ€™ compensation claim,â€ in
  conjunction with the other evidence Collins presented, we believe it can be
  considered as further evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 521, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992)
  (emphasis added). Â 

CONCLUSION

The record
  contains substantial evidence Collins sustained a loss of earning capacity.Â  Accordingly, the Appellate Panel did not err in finding
  Collins permanently and totally disabled.Â  Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s order
  is  

AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] The South Carolina General Assembly recently
  overhauled South Carolinaâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation laws.Â  These statutory changes
  affect claims for injuries occurring on or after July 1, 2007.Â  See 2007
  S.C. Acts 111, Part IV, Section 2 (â€œExcept as otherwise
  provided for in this act, this act takes effect July 1, 2007, or, if ratified
  after July 1, 2007, and except otherwise stated, upon approval by the Governor
  and applies to injuries that occur on or after this date.â€)
  (emphasis added).Â  The injury in this case occurred on October
  16, 1996.Â  Of note, however, is that injuries to the hips have now been
  scheduled.Â  
[2] This case is best resolved under the loss of earning
  capacity provision rather than the presumptively disabled provision due to a
  recent South Carolina Supreme Court case.Â  In Therrell v. Jerryâ€™s Inc.,
  370 S.C. 22, 24-25, 633 S.E.2d 893, 894 (2006), the claimant injured her
  rotator cuff, which is defined as part of the shoulder, but the Appellate Panel
  awarded her compensation under the scheduled injury of an arm.Â  The circuit
  court and this court affirmed focusing on the claimantâ€™s description of her
  injury as affecting her arm and on the fact that the medical evidence rated her
  injury as an impairment of the upper right extremity.Â  Id. at 25, 633
  S.E.2d at 894.Â  The Supreme Court found two general theories of recovery for
  workersâ€™ compensation exist: (1) the â€œfunctional impairmentâ€ approach, where
  the functional impairment that results from an injury is dispositive for
  determining under what schedule an injury is paid; and (2) the â€œsitus of the
  injuryâ€ approach, where the focus is on the actual injured body part to determine
  how to compensate an injury.Â  Id. at 26-28, 633 S.E.2d at 895-96.Â  In
  affirming this court as modified, the Supreme Court found South Carolina
  follows the situs of the injury approach.Â  Id. at 28, 633 S.E.2d at
  896.Â  The court cited Gilliam v. Woodside Mills, 319 S.C. 385, 461
  S.E.2d 818 (1995), as standing â€œfor the proposition that our scheduled
  compensation scheme focuses on the site of the injury and not the resulting
  functional limitation.â€Â  Therrell, 370 S.C. at 29, 633 S.E.2d at 897.Â 
  Accordingly, because most of Collinsâ€™s evidence focuses on his hip
  replacements, affirming based on an unscheduled injury and loss of earning
  capacity seems more appropriate than finding he was presumptively disabled due
  to a loss of both legs.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Daron Morgan, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal
  From Beaufort County
Howard
  P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished
  Opinion No. 2007-UP-396
Submitted
  September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed September 25, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Special Assistant
  Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Isaac
  McDuffie Stone, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Daron Morgan appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion for
  mistrial.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Morgan was
  convicted of the common law offense of escape.Â  Testimony at trial revealed
  that police officers received a call regarding a possible burglary at a
  residence.Â  Police proceeded to the scene where they found the back door of the
  residence partially open.Â  After announcing themselves and receiving no
  response, the officers entered the residence. Â Inside, they discovered Morgan
  and another man sleeping and a substance that appeared to be marijuana in a
  nearby bowl. Â The two were placed under arrest, but as they were leaving the
  scene, the arresting officer was distracted by a disturbance, and Morgan
  â€œsnatched awayâ€ and ran.Â   
Later, Morgan
  was arrested by a different officer, Jeff Purdy, at a nearby home. Â He was
  found hiding under the kitchen sink.Â  When apprehended, Morgan indicated the
  police would never find the missing handcuffs. Â 
At trial, Morgan
  made a motion in limine seeking to suppress the introduction of any evidence
  related to his subsequent arrest after his escape. He argued that the
  circumstances of that arrest and any statements he made were irrelevant and prejudicial.
  Â The trial court granted Morganâ€™s request in part.Â   

	[W]ith regard to
  the circumstances surrounding the arrest, I think it is [of] very questionable
  relevance.Â  But even if relevant . . . the prejudicial effect outweighs the
  probative value and so I would not permit the testimony surrounding the
  circumstances of his arrest other than to say that he was later located on such
  and such a day at such and such a location and placed under arrest for escape.Â 
  That would be the extent of the testimony that would be allowed there, not with
  regard to all the other circumstances. 

On direct
  examination, Officer Purdy testified that Morgan was discovered â€œhiding under
  the kitchen sink.â€Â  Defense counsel moved for a mistrial, but the trial court
  denied the motion reasoning that the literal interpretation of its ruling was
  followed although the spirit of the ruling was violated.Â  The trial court gave
  a curative instruction telling the jury to disregard any testimony concerning
  Morgan hiding under the sink.Â   
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
The decision to grant
  or deny a motion for mistrial is in the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State
    v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 310, 513 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999). Â That decision
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Morgan
  argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for mistrial.Â  He contends
  the solicitorâ€™s intention to obey or disobey the courtâ€™s ruling is irrelevant.Â 
  Instead, the prejudice to the defendant is the paramount consideration.Â  We
  agree, but conclude that there was no prejudice to Morgan.
The motion in
  limine pointed to several things the defense wanted to exclude from testimony.Â 
  The trial courtâ€™s ruling restricted admission of the â€œcircumstancesâ€
  surrounding Morganâ€™s second arrest, but approved testimony regarding the date
  and location of his arrest.Â  Both the motion in limine and the trial courtâ€™s
  ruling are somewhat ambiguous and subject to misinterpretation.Â  The trial
  court recognized as much in acknowledging that Officer Purdyâ€™s testimony was
  technically proper because it was limited to the location.Â  Notably, Officer
  Purdy did not testify regarding any statements made by Morgan upon his
  apprehension.
After
  denying Morganâ€™s motion for mistrial, the court offered a curative instruction
  telling the jury to â€œdisregard any testimony that the defendant was found,
  quote, hiding under the sink.Â  That issue is not relevant to any issue in this
  case and I instruct you to disregard and dismiss that from your mind, as I am
  striking that testimony from the testimony in this case.â€ Â â€œGenerally, a trial
  judgeâ€™s curative instruction is deemed to cure any error.â€Â  State v. Simmons,
  352 S.C. 342, 354, 573 S.E.2d 856, 863 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We see no special
  circumstances in this case whereby the curative instruction was not effective
  to remove any taint Officer Purdyâ€™s testimony may have caused.
Based on
  the foregoing, we cannot conclude the trial court abused its discretion in
  denying Morganâ€™s motion for mistrial.Â  Therefore the ruling of the trial court
  is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]   We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:

				v.

Appeal From Union County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-397
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  September 25, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Cleary, of Columbia; for Appellant
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Julie M. Thames, of Columbia; Kevin S. Brackett, of York; for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher
  Marquis Mobley appeals his conviction for attempting to purchase crack
  cocaine.Â  He argues the circuit court erred in denying his motion for directed
  verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]

FACTS 
On October 2, 2003, the Union City Police
  working in association with the Union County Sheriffâ€™s Office (collectively,
  the Police) arrested Carlos Bailey.Â  Bailey was believed to be the head of a crack
  cocaine drug ring operating in Union County.Â  Bailey was brought to the Police
  station, and a cell phone in his possession was confiscated.Â Â Â   
Baileyâ€™s
  cell phone rang and was answered by one of the officers.Â  The officer said
  â€œhelloâ€ and the caller responded by calling him â€œLoâ€ which was a known nickname
  for Carlos Bailey.Â  The caller then stated that he needed a â€œhookupâ€ and told
  the officer â€œI need a yard of hard.â€Â  After the caller stated that he was on
  Hancock Street, the officer instructed the caller to walk up and meet him at
  the â€œred light there at Monarch Highway and Highway 49 right in front of the
  church there.â€Â  The caller agreed, and the officer, accompanied by a second
  officer, drove to the site in an unmarked police car.Â Â Â   
As they
  neared their destination, the two officers observed a man walking up Hancock Street towards the agreed upon meeting place.Â  Baileyâ€™s cell phone rang again, and
  the same caller informed the officer that he was â€œon the way.â€Â  Once the Police
  observed a man[2] closing in on the meeting place, one officer dialed the number from the previously
  received call and observed the man answer his cell phone.Â  The officer then
  asked the man if he was â€œat the red light,â€ the officer observed the man
  talking into his cell phone and heard him respond through the phone that he was
  at the light.Â  The Police then pulled their vehicle up to the man, identified
  as Christopher Mobley, and placed him under arrest for attempting to purchase
  crack cocaine.Â  The Police searched Mobley incident to arrest and found
  one-hundred dollars in his left front pocket.Â  During the trial, three
  different officers testified that in their experience, a â€œyard of hardâ€ was a
  slang term used to delineate one-hundred dollars worth of crack cocaine.Â Â  
 
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Mobley motioned the court for a
  directed verdict, and the court denied this motion.Â  The jury convicted Mobley
  of attempting to purchase crack cocaine.Â  Mobley then moved for a judgment
  notwithstanding the verdict, and the trial court denied this motion and
  sentenced him to five years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the
  trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of
    evidence, not its weight.â€Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606
    S.E.2d 475, 477-78 (2004).Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this
    Court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most
    favorable to the state.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d
    525, 531 (1999). Where there is any direct evidence or any substantial
    circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused,
    an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Cherry,
  361 S.C. at 593-94, 606 S.E.2d at 478. See State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002) (on appeal from trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a
  directed verdict, appellate court may only reverse the trial court if there is
  no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling).

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Directed Verdict
Mobley contends the
  trial court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  Mobley maintains
  that there was no direct or circumstantial evidence to support a finding that
  he was guilty.Â  We disagree.
Section 44-53-375
  of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) states â€œ[a] person possessing or
  attempting to possess less than one gram of methamphetamine or cocaine base, as
  defined in Section 44-53-110,[3] is guilty . . . .â€Â  In this case, the State presented evidence that would allow
  a reasonable jury to find Mobley attempted to possess crack cocaine.Â  In taking
  the facts in the light most favorable to the State, we note the following.Â  The
  Police officers testified that in their experience a â€œyard of hardâ€ meant one
  hundred dollars worth of crack cocaine.Â  They further testified that when they
  arrested a man believed to be the head of a drug ring, Mobley called this manâ€™s
  cell phone, said he needed a hook-up, and asked for a â€œyard of hard.â€Â  In
  furtherance of this request, Mobley agreed to meet at a specified place to attain
  the â€œyard of hard.â€Â  The Police observed Mobley speaking to them on his cell
  phone after they had called the number from the dealerâ€™s phone, and Mobley told
  them he was at the agreed upon meeting place.Â  When Mobley was arrested, the
  police found exactly one-hundred dollars in Mobleyâ€™s possession.Â  We find that
  contrary to Mobleyâ€™s argument, he did make sufficient overt acts towards
  purchasing the drugs by walking to the designated meeting place to make the
  purchase.Â  We find there was sufficient evidence to support the denial of a
  directed verdict motion.Â  Therefore, we find no error by the trial court.
CONCLUSION
We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of the directed
  verdict motion.Â  Based on the foregoing, Mobleyâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] One of the officers recognized the man as Christopher
  Mobley from previous interactions with him.
[3] â€œâ€˜Crack cocaineâ€™ means an alkaloidal cocaine or
  freebase form of cocaine, which is the end product of a chemical alteration
  whereby the cocaine in salt form is converted to a form suitable for smoking.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-110 (Supp. 2006).Â  Since no drugs were actually
  exchanged in this case, this definition is immaterial.

  that she can provide minimally acceptable care to the three minor children.Â 
  Additionally, the court found termination was in the best interests of the
  children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006).Â  Upon reviewing the record and the family courtâ€™s

  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is affirmed.[1]
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, CJ., and
  HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â 
  This is a workers compensation case.Â  The single commissioner awarded appellant
  Bob J. Weatherford, the claimant, additional workersâ€™ compensation benefits,
  finding he had suffered a change of condition for the worse as the result of an
  earlier admitted workplace injury.Â  Respondents, Jordanâ€™s Scrap Metal Co.,
  Inc., and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, appealed the single commissionerâ€™s
  order to the full commission; however, the appellate panel dismissed the appeal
  and assessed hearing costs against them when their counsel failed to appear for
  oral argument.Â  Respondents
  then appealed to the circuit court, which issued an order purporting to reverse
  the appellate panelâ€™s order based on a lack of substantial evidence to support
  the award of benefits to Weatherford. Â We vacate the order of the circuit court.[1]
1.Â  Respondentsâ€™ complaints
  about the sufficiency of the evidence supporting Weatherfordâ€™s claim concerned
  the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Any challenge to this order cannot, under the
  Administrative Procedures Act, be the subject of judicial review by the circuit
  court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A) (Supp. 2006) (stating that one
  â€œwho is aggrieved by a final decision in a contested case is entitled to
  judicial review) (emphasis added); Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C.
  490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989) (referring to the full commission as the
  â€œultimate fact finderâ€ in workersâ€™ compensation cases).
2.Â  In the
  appealed order, the circuit court appears to have assumed the appellate panel
  adopted the findings of the single commissioner.[2]Â 
  To the contrary, however, the appellate panel made no direct or indirect
  findings of fact concerning the merits of either Weatherfordâ€™s claim or the
  single commissionerâ€™s order. Â Instead, the appellate panel limited its decision
  to a dismissal of Respondentsâ€™ appeal with prejudice on procedural grounds and
  a mandate that they were to pay the hearing costs. Â Respondents neither moved
  to reinstate their appeal nor argued the appellate panel was incorrect in
  finding that they failed to perfect it; therefore, the dismissal of
  Respondentsâ€™ appeal of the single commissionerâ€™s order stands.Â  See Parker
    v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 288 S.C. 304, 308, 342 S.E.2d 403, 405 (1986) (â€œNo objection can be made to an appealable order from which no
  appeal has been taken.â€); Buckner v. Preferred Mut. Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 161, 177 S.E.2d 544, 544 (1970) (stating an unchallenged ruling â€œright or wrong, is the law of this case and requires affirmanceâ€).Â 
 
Based on the
  foregoing, we hold the circuit court exceeded its authority under the
  Administrative Procedures Act.Â  We therefore vacate the appealed order in its
  entirety and reinstate both the single commissionerâ€™s award and the appellate panelâ€™s assessment of hearing costs
  against Respondents.
VACATED.
HEARN,
  C.J., ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The appealed order states:Â  â€œThe finding of the
  Commissioner, and subsequently of the Full Commission, both lacks substantial
  evidence and is controlled by an error of law, in that no expert medical
  testimony was presented.â€

THIS OPINION HAS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

				CSB Development

Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-402
Heard May 9, 2007 â€“ Filed September 28,
  2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Keating L. Simons, III, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Drew A. Laughlin, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent D&N
  Realty.
				Thomas Justin Finn, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent HHI Corporation,
  Limited.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant
  claims the lower court erred in finding the deed restrictions at issue were
  real covenants which ran with the land and in failing to give effect to a
  cancellation of the deed restrictions.[1]Â 
  We affirm.
FACTS
This appeal involves multiple contiguous ocean front lots.Â 
  Appellant is the owner of Lots 3 and 4.Â  By deed dated June 28, 2001, Respondent
  D&N Realty purchased Lot 2, which is located adjacent to Lot 3, and
  subdivided it into four lots. Respondent D&N Realty has sold three of the
  subdivided lots and currently owns Lot 2(B).Â  By deed dated July 29, 2002,
  Respondent HHI Corporation purchased Lot 2(D), one of the lots subdivided from Lot 2, from Respondent D&N Realty.Â  Each of the lots involved in this action was once
  owned by Josephine Driessen.Â  On August 30, 1972, Driessen sold Lots 3 and 4 to
  Roscoe and Clara Mae Robinson.Â  The deed for the transaction contained the
  following restrictions:

	This conveyance is made by the Grantor and accepted by the
  Grantees subject to the restriction that that area shown on said plat as lying
  between the drainage ditch and the mean high water mark of the waters of the
  Atlantic Ocean shall be left unimproved and no structure of any nature
  whatsoever erected thereon without express written consent of the Grantor which
  may be arbitrarily withheld.Â  With regard to the remainder of the premises
  located west of the above-mentioned drainage ditch, it is understood and agreed
  that each of these lots is to be used for single-family residential purposes
  only and that no commercial activity of any nature whatsoever shall be
  established, kept or maintained thereon.

By written
  instrument recorded on September 28, 1972, the parties to the initial
  transaction altered the deed by rescinding the restrictions recited above and
  replacing them with the following:  

	It is understood and agreed by and between JOSEPHINE DRIESSEN and
  ROSCOE ROBINSON and CLARA MAE ROBINSON that Lots 3 and 4 as described in that
  Deed recorded in the Office of the Clerk of Court for Beaufort County, South
  Carolina, in Deed Book 201 at Page 936 shall not be used for construction of
  any type of amusement building thereon, nor shall any type of amusement
  facility be operated thereon.Â  It is further understood and agreed that ROSCOE
  ROBINSON and CLARA MAE ROBINSON, their Heirs and Assigns, shall not in any way
  alter or destroy the sand dunes existing on the property.

Driessen
  died on October 27, 1989.Â  On June 5, 2001, Appellant acquired the property
  from the Robinsons.Â  The deed from the Robinsons to the Appellant inadvertently
  contained the exact same restrictions originally included in the deed from
  Driessen to Roscoe and Clara Mae Robinson.Â Â Â   
On
  February 25, 2003, the Robinsons issued a second deed to correct the â€œscrivenerâ€™s
  errorâ€ by entirely removing the restrictions contained in the first deed to
  Appellant and replacing it with the following restrictions:  

	Lots 3 and 4 as described in that Deed recorded in Office of the
  Clerk of Court for Beaufort County, South Carolina, in Deed Book 201 at Page
  936 shall not be used for construction of any type of amusement building
  thereon, nor shall any type of amusement facility be operated thereon.Â 
  Further, [Grantee], its successor and assigns, shall not in any way alter or destroy
  the sand dunes existing on the property.

On
  March 8, 2003, Driessenâ€™s surviving heirs executed an instrument titled
  â€œAGREEMENT (Quitclaim Deed with Limited Warranty)â€.Â  This agreement purported
  to release and relinquish any and all rights under the deed restrictions,
  cancel the deed restrictions, and render the restrictions null and void.Â 
 
Respondents
  initiated these actions seeking declaratory judgments as to the applicability
  of the restrictions with respect to Appellantâ€™s property.[2]Â  Respondents claimed standing based
  on their properties and the property of Appellant being adjacent and sharing a
  common source of title, and Respondents claimed the restrictions in Appellantâ€™s
  deed were valid and enforceable as real covenants which ran with the land. Â Appellant
  contended the restrictions were personal to the Grantor and did not run with
  the land and contended the Respondents, as strangers to the transaction between
  Appellant and the Robinsons, lacked standing to seek a declaration or enforcement
  of the restrictions.
The
  lower court framed the issue as whether the restrictions contained in the
  instrument recorded â€œon September 28, 1972, [are] real covenant[s] running with
  the land that can be enforced by subsequent grantees of Josephine Driessenâ€¦.â€Â 
  By order dated March 5, 2004, the lower court held the restrictions were â€œreal
  covenant[s], running with the land, enforceable byâ€ Respondents.Â  This appeal
  follows.Â   
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
â€œA
  suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined
  by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991). In the present case, the underlying
  issue is a declaration as to whether or not the restrictive covenants are
  enforceable.Â  Therefore, this is an equitable action.Â  See Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 165, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006).Â  In
  an equity action, the appellate court may review the evidence to determine the
  facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence.Â  Florence County Sch.
    Dist. #2 v. Interkal, Inc., 348 S.C. 446, 450, 559 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct.
  App. 2002).Â  Furthermore, the appellate court is not bound by the trial courtâ€™s
  legal determinations.Â  Swindler v. Swindler, 355 S.C. 245, 249, 584
  S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 2003).  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Deed
  Restrictions
The lower court based its holding that the restrictions were real
  covenants and, therefore, ran with the land on the language contained in the
  preamble and express wordage of the instrument recorded on September 28, 1972.Â 
  The preamble to the instrument states that the â€œDeed of Conveyance did contain
  certain restrictions and limitations running with the landâ€ and that Driessen
  was then â€œdesirous of releasing and/or modifyingâ€ the restrictions.Â  The text
  of the instrument states that Driessen â€œin substitution thereof does herewith
  impose the following restrictions upon the said property in lieu of those
  previously governing the sameâ€:

	Â It is understood and agreed by and between JOSEPHINE DRIESSEN and
  ROSCOE ROBINSON and CLARA MAE ROBINSON that Lots 3 and 4 as described in that
  Deed recorded in Office of the Clerk of Court for Beaufort County, South
  Carolina, in Deed Book 201 at Page 936 shall not be used for construction of
  any type of amusement building thereon, nor shall any type of amusement
  facility be operated thereon.Â  It is further understood and agreed that ROSCOE
  ROBINSON and CLARA MAE ROBINSON, their Heirs and Assigns, shall not in any way
  alter or destroy the sand dunes existing on the property.Â  

â€œA restrictive covenant runs with the land, and is thus
  enforceable by a successor-in-interest, if the covenanting party intended that
  it run with the land, and the covenant touches and concerns the land.â€Â  West v. Newberry Elec. Co-op.,  357 S.C. 537, 542, 593 S.E.2d 500, 503 (Ct.
  App. 2004) (citing Marathon
    Fin. Co. v. HHC Liquidation Corp., 325 S.C. 589, 604, 483 S.E.2d 757, 765 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â  A
  party seeking to enforce a covenant must show it applies to the property either
  by its express language or by a plain and unmistakable implication.Â  Sea
    Pines Plantation Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C. 266, 363 S.E.2d 891 (1987).Â  
 

	Restrictive
  covenants are to be construed most strictly against the grantor and persons
  seeking to enforce them, and liberally in favor of the grantee, all doubts
  being resolved in favor of a free use of property and against restrictions.
  This rule, however, obtains only where the parties have failed to express their
  meaning with sufficient clarity to enable the court to say that its construction
  is plain and admits of no doubt; the rule will not be applied to defeat the
  obvious purpose of the restrictions, nor does it require an unnatural and
  strained construction of the words used; and before giving effect to the rule
  the court will have recourse to every aid, rule, or cannon of construction to
  ascertain the intention of the parties, since it is the duty of the courts to
  enforce, not to make, contracts. 

Stanton v. Gulf Oil Corp., 232 S.C. 148, 151, 101
  S.E.2d 250, 251 (1957) (citation omitted).
The express language of the preamble to the instrument executed by
  Driessen reveals that the original restrictions were intended to run with the
  land.Â  The language of the instrument also reveals that the purpose for
  executing the instrument was to substitute the original restrictions with the
  newly drafted restrictions.Â  Accordingly, the newly drafted restrictions would
  have the same future application as the original restrictions.Â  The instrument
  clearly illustrates Driessenâ€™s intent to have the restrictions run with the
  land.Â  Moreover, as to the restriction prohibiting the altering or destruction
  of the sand dunes existing on Lot 3 and 4, the language of the restriction
  expressly states that that restriction is to apply to the heirs and assigns of
  the Robinsons.Â   
The
  generally accepted test provides that the benefit of a covenant meets the touch
  and concern requirement if â€œthe covenanteeâ€™s legal interest in land is rendered
  more valuable by the covenantâ€™s performance.â€ 5 R. Powell & P. Rohan, Powell
    on Real Property Â 673[2], at
  60-49-60-50 (rev. ed. 1996).Â  The restrictions at issue render the surrounding lots more valuable.Â  Eugene J. Laurich, the self
  proclaimed â€œD in D&N Realtyâ€, testified that the restriction on Lot 3 and 4
  made Lot 2 more valuable because they insured Lots 2(B) and 2(D) would be
  entitled to an unobstructed view down the beach and across Folly Creek.Â  In his
  testimony, he cited the restrictions as being the reason D&N Realty decided
  to cease its initial efforts to purchase Lots 3 and 4 and to purchase Lot 2 instead. Â These restrictions limit
  the use of the property by prohibiting
  the building or operation of any amusement facility on Lot 3 and 4 and by
  prohibiting the alteration or destruction of the sand dunes on Lots 3 and 4. Â The
  restrictions also increase the value of Respondentsâ€™ property. Â Â Accordingly, the restrictions touch and concern the
  land. See West v. Newberry
    Elec. Co-op.,  357 S.C. 537, 543,
  593 S.E.2d 500, 503 (Ct. App. 2004); See also Marathon Finance Co. v. HHC Liquidation Corp.,  325 S.C. 589, 606, 483 S.E.2d 757, 766 (Ct.
  App. 1997)(Cureton, J. dissenting).
Â Because we find Driessen intended to have the restrictions run
  with the land and find the restrictions touch and concern the land, we affirm
  the lower courtâ€™s determination that the restrictions are real covenants which
  run with the land and, therefore, are enforceable by Respondents.Â   
Cancellation
  of the Deed Restrictions
Our
  determination of the first issue is dispositive of this issue. See Futch v. McAllister Towing of
    Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an
  appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a
  prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
For
  the reasons stated above, the order of the lower court isÂ   
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The parties and the lower court refer to the
  pertinent section of the instrument as being a restriction.Â  There are two
  separate restrictions included in the section.Â  The first restriction is a
  prohibition against the building or operation of any amusement facility on Lots
  3 and 4, and the second restriction is a prohibition against altering or destroying
  the sand dunes on Lots 3 and 4.
[2] These actions were consolidated and tried together,
  and the parties submitted a consolidated record on appeal.Â  Accordingly, we
  have consolidated the opinions for these two cases.Â
